titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the National Labor Committee Records WAG.347
titlestmt.author: Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-11-30 15:12:43 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: National Labor Committee Records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights

physdesc.extent: in 53 record cartons, 14 manuscript boxes, 4 half manuscript boxes, 2 media boxes, and 1 flat-file folder

did.abstract: The National Labor Committee (later known as the Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights) is a non-profit, non-governmental organization that investigates human and labor rights abuses committed by corporations, advocates on behalf of the workers in these conditions, and publishes findings in an effort to influence corporate policy and public opinion. In 1986, Charles Kernaghan joined the organization and became its Executive Director in 1990. The NLC's investigations and subsequent media campaigns in the 1990s focused on labor abuses such as child labor, low wages, and poor working conditions in factories connected to major corporations, such as Nike, Wal-Mart, and the Walt Disney Company, in addition to celebrity clothing labels, such as Kathie Lee Gifford's. In 2011, the NLC changed its name to the Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights, and in 2017 suspended operations. This collection consists of materials created and collected by the National Labor Committee between 1981 and 2015 documenting their daily operations, investigative operations, advocacy efforts concerning human and labor rights abuses committed by corporations, with particular emphasis on efforts to end child labor and improve the conditions of workers in sweatshops in the developing world. Materials in this collection include documentation of the NLC's prominent anti-sweatshop campaigns targeting corporations such as The Gap, the Walt Disney Company, Wal-mart, Liz Claiborne, Nike, and Major League Baseball, as well as celebrity labels such as Kathie Lee Gifford. Campaign documents include correspondence, press releases, press kits, action memoranda, newspaper and magazine clippings, reports produced by NLC or related organizations, and photographs of factory workers and working conditions, video recordings of interviews with factory workers. The majority of the campaigns documented in this collection focus on factories located in China, Bangladesh, and Central America. The files are paper, electronic, and audiovisual.
did.langmaterial: The majority of materials are in English, with many documents and audiovisual footage in Spanish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of materials created and collected by the National Labor Committee (later known as the Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights) between 1981 and 2015 documenting their daily operations, investigative operations, advocacy efforts concerning human and labor rights abuses committed by corporations, with particular emphasis on efforts to end child labor and improve the conditions of workers in sweatshops in the developing world. Materials in this collection include documentation of the National Labor Committee's (NLC) prominent anti-sweatshop campaigns targeting corporations such as The Gap, the Walt Disney Company, Wal-mart, Liz Claiborne, Nike, and Major League Baseball, as well as celebrity labels such as Kathie Lee Gifford. Campaign documents include correspondence, press releases, press kits, action memoranda, newspaper and magazine clippings, reports produced by NLC or related organizations, and photographs of factory workers and working conditions, video recordings of interviews with factory workers. The majority of the campaigns documented in this collection focus on factories located in China, Bangladesh, and Central America. Many articles and reports distributed by the NLC were written by Charles Kernaghan, Executive Director of the NLC and Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights. The files are paper, electronic, and audiovisual.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by the National Labor Committee was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Barbara Briggs in March 2018; the accession number associated with this gift is 2018.060.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; National Labor Committee Records; WAG 347; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused in archival boxes and folders, and described at the collection-level with a box-inventory. Audiovisual and born-digital items were identified and inventoried, but have not been forensically analyzed or imaged. New York University Libraries follows professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity of the content.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, (212) 998-2630 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The National Labor Committee (later known as the Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights) is a non-profit, non-governmental organization that investigates human and labor rights abuses committed by corporations, advocates on behalf of the workers in these conditions, and publishes findings in an effort to influence corporate policy and public opinion. The NLC was founded in 1980 by Jack Sheinkman, then President of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union; Doug Frazer, President of the United Auto Workers; and Bill Winpisinger, President of the International Association of Machinists. The organization was originally founded with a mission to assist union members in Central American who were victims of political violence, but later expanded its focus to defend human and workers rights, and further the global anti-sweatshop movement. In 1986, Charles Kernaghan joined the organization and became its Executive Director in 1990. The NLC's investigations and subsequent media campaigns in the 1990s focused on labor abuses such as child labor, low wages, and poor working conditions in factories connected to major corporations, such as Nike, Wal-Mart, and the Walt Disney Company, in addition to celebrity clothing labels, such as Kathie Lee Gifford's. In 2011, the NLC changed its name to the Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights, and in 2017 suspended operations.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: 13 boxes of financial records were appraised out of the collection and shredded. 60 oversize photograph reproductions were discarded. Toys and clothing were sampled.
